chapter: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 1: Li Jing, a young tourist boy from the Keshan district of China visits India for a novel scientific 
exchange program. He presents to the ER with severe breathlessness. His previous medical 
records give the diagnosis of congestive cardiomyopathy. Which micronutrient deficiency is 
most likely seen in this case?
questions.explanation:
Keshan disease is due to the deficiency of selenium. It is a congestive cardiomyopathy that is 
caused due to dietary deficiency of selenium. Keshan is a county of China where the symptoms were noted first. The disease is also endemic to 
that province. The patients will mostly present with acute breathlessness, paroxysms of 
exacerbated attacks. Selenium is an enzyme cofactor for glutathione peroxidase, which prevents oxidative damage. Note: Kashin Beck disease is a chronic, endemic osteochondropathy due to selenium deficiency.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 2: Anika, a 6-year-old girl good at sprint events, has been avoiding her track practices over the 
recent few weeks. Her mother informs that she skips her classes owing to her knee pain. Her 
X-ray reveals subperiosteal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pseudoparalysis which is a feature of scurvy - vitamin C 
deficiency The subperiosteal haemorrhages in the lower limb bones can cause acute swelling and pain; the 
condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. The child refuses to walk because of the 
pain; hence, it is called pseudoparalysis.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 3: A four-year-old boy presents with petechiae, perifollicular haemorrhages, and swollen, 
bleeding gums. On examination, you identify the child to be malnourished and suspect 
scurvy. Which of the following is/are part of biochemical functions of the vitamin deficient in 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
Scurvy is a deficiency of vitamin C. The correct answer is 1, 3, 5. Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin, which cannot be synthesized in the human body due to 
deficient L-gulonolactone oxidase enzyme. Breast milk contains adequate amounts of ascorbic 
acid, whereas the pasteurisation of animal milk at high temperature destroys vitamin C. Functions of Vitamin C / Ascorbic Acid : • Synthesis of collagen (Hydroxylation of proline, which is vital for collagen; in the formation of 
the bone matrix). • Neurotransmitter metabolism (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to 
serotonin) • Cholesterol metabolism (conversion of cholesterol to steroid hormones and bile acids) • Biosynthesis of carnitine 158 
Sold by @itachibot • Antioxidation (electron donor) • For the cellular and immunologic functions of the hematopoietic system The image below shows peri-follicular haemorrhages.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 4: A child in your unit is receiving treatment for chronic diarrhea. His diet history is remarkable 
for a high phytate-rich diet. His labs reveal low serum zinc. Which of the following findings is 
least likely to be seen in this child?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chronic zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency affects both 
cell-mediated and humoral immunity. The cell-mediated immunity is impaired predominantly, as 
zinc is essential for T-cell division, maturation, and differentiation. In a child with a phytate-rich diet, a chronic deficiency of zinc and iron usually co-exist. Isolated 
chronic zinc deficiency can be seen in the setting of a child suffering from chronic diarrhoea, 
repeated pneumonia or chest infections, and congenital malabsorption disorders. Chronic zinc deficiency manifests as: • Dwarfism • Hypogonadism • Dermatitis of extremities and around orifices • T-cell immunodeficiency • Diarrhoea The features of acute zinc deficiency include: • Decreased growth • Poor wound healing • Diarrhea 159 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 5: The X-ray of a 7-year-old child diagnosed with scurvy showed the white line of Frankel. This 
would be best described as?

options.c: Opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centres of ossification

questions.explanation: Calcified cartilage at metaphysis is known as the white line of Frankel and it is seen in scurvy.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 6: The eldest child of a ragpicker from the urban slums of Bandra presents with severe lower 
limb pain. Examination reveals swelling of costochondral junctions. The X-ray image 
obtained is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? 152 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette involving a neglected child (eldest usually) from a poor socio-economic 
background with bone pains due to subperiosteal haemorrhages and scorbutic rosary (swelling of 
costochondral junctions) is suggestive of scurvy. Radiological features of scurvy: Early changes • The white line of Frankel on the ends of the shafts of the tibia and fibula • Wimberger ring sign: Sclerotic rings around the epiphyses of the femur and tibia. Late changes • Trummerfeld zone: Zones of destruction in the femur and tibia • Pelkan spur at the cortical end The image sums up the X-ray features noted in scurvy. The image attached below shows a child with the scorbutic rosary. 160 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 7: A farmer from Hoshiarpur, Punjab rushes his 10-year-old boy to the paediatric ER. The father 
complained of intractable nausea and diarrhoea in the child. On examination, the child has a 
garlicky odour and is severely dehydrated. You notice neurologic manifestations along with 
nail and hair changes in the child. Which of the following mineral toxicities would you 
suspect?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of acute selenium toxicity. Selenium toxicity is characterised by nausea, diarrhoea, neurologic manifestations, nail and hair 
changes, and garlicky odour. It is commonly seen in areas where drinking water and the collated 
soil is extremely rich in selenium. In India, selenium toxicity is endemic to agricultural sites 
located in the states of Punjab and Haryana. The presentations are usually acute in nature rather 
than chronic. Chromium toxicity (Option - B) is commonly seen only in adults with occupational exposure. 
Chromium is a pulmonary irritant and the symptoms are predominantly respiratory complaints 
similar to bronchitis. They also cause chronic allergic dermatitis and is carcinogenic too. Molybdenum toxicity (Option C) is very rarely seen in humans. It manifests usually as acute 
diarrhoea. Iodine toxicity (Option D) can range from mild GI illness to chronic thyroid dysfunction varying 
from hyperthyroidism to papillary thyroid carcinoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 8: A 2-month-old infant is brought to your OPD. The mother complains that the child refuses to 
feed and is not gaining adequate weight. She has recently noticed changes in her hair. On 
examination, the hair seems to resemble steel to wood. Labs reveal low serum copper levels. 
What is the diagnosis? 153 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Menkes disease or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease 
caused by copper deficiency. It is an X■linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A which encodes for a 
copper-transporting ATPase■ polypeptide, leading to the disruption of copper transport in the 
intestine. The clinical features include: • Failure to thrive (First presenting complaint) 161 
Sold by @itachibot • Neurological degeneration (myeloneuropathy) • Infections • Hair abnormalities (kinky hair with pili troti seen on a Trichogram). • These infants have a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge, pudgy 
cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip, and doughy skin. A therapeutic trial with copper-histidinase may be helpful. Option A: De Vivo disease is a metabolic disorder due to GLUT1 deficiency. Options C and D: Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-beck disease (endemic 
osteochondropathy) are caused by selenium deficiency. The image attached below shows the cherubic appearance of the child with kinky hair. The 
subsequent picture attached shows pili troti seen under the trichogram. 162 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 9: The anxious mother of a 5-month-old baby informs you that the baby incessantly cries on 
touching or lifting. The baby is comfortable when it is made to lie down. Diet history is 
significant for the child being fed exclusively on cow’s milk. What could be the probable 
cause?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of scurvy. A child who presents with a cry on touching or lifting 
is usually due to subperiosteal haemorrhages. Scurvy/Barlow’s Disease is caused due to the deficiency of vitamin c, especially in children fed 
predominantly on heat-treated cow’s milk. High temperature destroys vitamin C. JRA - Juvenile Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) rarely presents in infancy. Rickets (Option C) presents with growth retardation or other features such as craniotabes, 
craniosynostosis in infancy. It is generally associated with individuals who have a milk deficient 
diet. Caffey’s disease (Option D) is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age 
with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone 
involved.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 10: A child is born with the following abnormality. What advice do you give to the mother, with 
regards to the next pregnancy?

options.c: 400 mcg of folic acid after confirmation of pregnancy

questions.explanation:
The given image shows spina bifida, the most common neural tube defect (NTD). 4000 mcg of 
folic acid periconceptionally is given to prevent NTDs in subsequent pregnancies. The normal dose of folic acid in pregnancy is 400 mcg (0.4 mg). However, the history of 
a previous pregnancy with an NTD raises the risk of another NTD in subsequent pregnancies. An 
increased dose of folic acid is thus prophylactically given during the periconceptional period to 
prevent NTD in the next child.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 11: A 10-year-old girl presented with the triad of diarrhoea, dermatitis, and delayed mental 
development. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test. Which of 
the following statement is false regarding the vitamin deficient in this child?

options.a: Carcinoid syndrome can cause secondary deficiency of this vitamin
options.c: It decreases the levels of lipoprotein (a)
options.d: Most fatal complication with high dose of this vitamin is fulminant hepatitis

questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Pellagra secondary to Hartnup's disease. The vitamin 
deficient in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan and not tyrosine. Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Its deficiency occurs in a maize-based diet 
(maize is deficient in tryptophan), carcinoid syndrome (all the tryptophan is converted to 
serotonin), and hartnup disease (defective absorption from intestine and kidney). Niacin is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein(a) levels significantly. It also results 
in a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL cholesterol. Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds)- • Diarrhoea • Dermatitis (Cassal's necklace) • Dementia • Finally death. Niacin toxicity manifests as: • Prostaglandin mediated cutaneous flushing 163 
Sold by @itachibot • Glucose intolerance • Fulminant hepatitis (most fatal complication) Hartnup's disease is due to impaired renal and intestinal absorption of tryptophan and other 
neutral amino acids. It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of 
muscle control), delayed mental development, diarrhoea and dermatitis (pellagra-like 
symptoms as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin). Diagnosis of niacin deficiency secondary to 
hartnup's disease is based on neutral aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds 
detected by the Obermeyer test. Image: Casal's necklace
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 12: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and 
mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since 
weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of 
acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in the intestinal zinc-specific 
transporter gene. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management. It classically presents 
while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk. The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, 
chronic diarrhea, and alopecia. Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous 
plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the 
edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U■shaped or 
horseshoe■shaped appearance. Investigations would reveal low serum zinc. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 
mg/kg/24 hour) Option A: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is the classical triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema and 
recurrent pyogenic infections. No history of bleeding rules out this option. Option C: Epidermolysis bullosa presents as bullous lesions in pressure handling areas. 164 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: In atopic dermatitis usually the lesions will be itchy and distributed in extensor aspects 
(flexural in adults).
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 13: A young school-going girl, a known case of seizure disorder controlled with valproic acid, 
complaints of constant bullying by her classmates for her patchy hair loss. Local scalp 
examination reveals scaly dermatitis and hair loss with intermittent constrictions. Which of 
the following deficiencies is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Biotin (Vitamin H or Vitamin B7) deficiency can cause alopecia, dermatitis (periorificial), and 
thinning of hair. It is commonly seen in individuals who are on long term valproate therapy. Scarring alopecia with islands of dense hair referred to as intermittent constrictions is classically 
seen in biotin deficiency.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 14: A 2-day-old neonate is noted to have multifocal-clonic seizures. These seizures are 
unresponsive to pharmacologic therapy. Which vitamin dependency is responsible for such 
seizures?
questions.explanation:
Pyridoxine is one of the causes of refractory seizures in the neonatal period and infancy. Pyridoxine and pyridoxal dependency disorders can cause severe seizures. These seizures, which 
are often multifocal clonic, usually start during the first few hours of life. It involves a mutation in 
the ALDH7A1 gene causing a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the degradation of 
I- alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question: Question 15: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with the deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Early symptoms of thiamine deficiency include peripheral neuropathy, irritability, loss of deep 
tendon reflexes, and proprioception. As the disease progresses, increased intracranial pressure, 
meningismus, and coma develop. 165 
Sold by @itachibot Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It 
is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice based monotonous 
diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity 
assessment. Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El

questions.question:
Question 16: During the routine ophthalmic examination of a 6-year- old child as a part of a school health 
survey, you notice the following finding as shown in the image. This is characteristically 
associated with deficiency of 156 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows corneal vascularization, which is characteristic of Riboflavin deficiency. 
Other features include glossitis, cheilosis, and photophobia collectively called ariboflavinosis. The image below shows Cheilosis and glossitis 166 
Sold by @itachibot Fluid and Electrolyte Disorders
questions.chapter_heading: Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins   Trace El
